author: HCAndersen
text: WE are in a rich, happy house, where the master, the servants, the friends of the family are full of joy and felicity.

author: HCAndersen
text: For on this day a son and heir has been born, and mother and child are doing well.

author: HCAndersen
text: The lamp in the bed-chamber had been partly shaded, and the windows were covered with heavy curtains of some costly silken material.

author: HCAndersen
text: The carpet was thick and soft, like a covering of moss.

author: HCAndersen
text: Everything invited to slumber, everything had a charming look of repose; and so the nurse had discovered, for she slept; and well she might sleep, while everything around her told of happiness and blessing.

author: HCAndersen
text: The guardian angel of the house leaned against the head of the bed; while over the child was spread, as it were, a net of shining stars, and each star was a pearl of happiness.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the good stars of life had brought their gifts to the newly born; here sparkled health, wealth, fortune, and love; in short, there seemed to be everything for which man could wish on earth.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Everything has been bestowed here," said the guardian angel.

author: HCAndersen
text: "No, not everything," said a voice near him- the voice of the good angel of the child; "one fairy has not yet brought her gift, but she will, even if years should elapse, she will bring her gift; it is the last pearl that is wanting."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Wanting!" cried the guardian angel; "nothing must be wanting here; and if it is so, let us fetch it; let us seek the powerful fairy; let us go to her."

author: HCAndersen
text: "She will come, she will come some day unsought!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Her pearl must not be missing; it must be there, that the crown, when worn, may be complete.

author: HCAndersen
text: Where is she to be found?

author: HCAndersen
text: Where does she dwell?" said the guardian angel.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Tell me, and I will procure the pearl."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Will you do that?" replied the good angel of the child.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Then I will lead you to her directly, wherever she may be.

author: HCAndersen
text: She has no abiding place; she rules in the palace of the emperor, sometimes she enters the peasant's humble cot; she passes no one without leaving a trace of her presence.

author: HCAndersen
text: She brings her gift with her, whether it is a world or a bauble.

author: HCAndersen
text: To this child she must come.

author: HCAndersen
text: You think that to wait for this time would be long and useless.

author: HCAndersen
text: Well, then, let us go for this pearl- the only one lacking amidst all this wealth."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then hand-in-hand they floated away to the spot where the fairy was now lingering.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was in a large house with dark windows and empty rooms, in which a peculiar stillness reigned.

author: HCAndersen
text: A whole row of windows stood open, so that the rude wind could enter at its pleasure, and the long white curtains waved to and fro in the current of air.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the centre of one of the rooms stood an open coffin, in which lay the body of a woman, still in the bloom of youth and very beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
text: Fresh roses were scattered over her.

author: HCAndersen
text: The delicate folded hands and the noble face glorified in death by the solemn, earnest look, which spoke of an entrance into a better world, were alone visible.

author: HCAndersen
text: Around the coffin stood the husband and children, a whole troop, the youngest in the father's arms.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were come to take a last farewell look of their mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: The husband kissed her hand, which now lay like a withered leaf, but which a short time before had been diligently employed in deeds of love for them all.

author: HCAndersen
text: Tears of sorrow rolled down their cheeks, and fell in heavy drops on the floor, but not a word was spoken.

author: HCAndersen
text: The silence which reigned here expressed a world of grief.

author: HCAndersen
text: With silent steps, still sobbing, they left the room.

author: HCAndersen
text: A burning light remained in the room, and a long, red wick rose far above the flame, which fluttered in the draught of air.

author: HCAndersen
text: Strange men came in and placed the lid of the coffin over the dead, and drove the nails firmly in; while the blows of the hammer resounded through the house, and echoed in the hearts that were bleeding.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Whither art thou leading me?" asked the guardian angel.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Here dwells no fairy whose pearl could be counted amongst the best gifts of life."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, she is here; here in this sacred hour," replied the angel, pointing to a corner of the room; and there,- where in her life-time, the mother had taken her seat amidst flowers and pictures: in that spot, where she, like the blessed fairy of the house, had welcomed husband, children, and friends, and, like a sunbeam, had spread joy and cheerfulness around her, the centre and heart of them all,- there, in that very spot, sat a strange woman, clothed in long, flowing garments, and occupying the place of the dead wife and mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was the fairy, and her name was "Sorrow."

author: HCAndersen
text: A hot tear rolled into her lap, and formed itself into a pearl, glowing with all the colors of the rainbow.

author: HCAndersen
text: The angel seized it: the, pearl glittered like a star with seven-fold radiance.

author: HCAndersen
text: The pearl of Sorrow, the last, which must not be wanting, increases the lustre, and explains the meaning of all the other pearls.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Do you see the shimmer of the rainbow, which unites earth to heaven?"

author: HCAndersen
text: So has there been a bridge built between this world and the next.

author: HCAndersen
text: Through the night of the grave we gaze upwards beyond the stars to the end of all things.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then we glance at the pearl of Sorrow, in which are concealed the wings which shall carry us away to eternal happiness.
